creator: gillouxGaillard@wanadoo.fr
text:
Methods in Ant tasks should offer their services to subclasses. For example, 
when the CvsTagDiff executes, it splits its work into:
- construct the cvs command line
- parse the RDiff (that returns CvsTagEntry[] entries)
- write these entries.
A sub class that want to do something else than writing the entries may benefit 
from the above methods being protected instaed of private.

I found a similar example in the Get task.

There is no problem to copy the code when creating a new Task, but it would be 
better to inherit from (reuse) the existing one.

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text:
Rather than generalize what normally happens in this case is that a user can
submit an enhancement request on a per-task or per-concern basis.  These
requests are usually honored, but continuing to write "normal" Java classes and
examining access modifiers piecemeal helps us ensure we won't inadvertently
expose too much too soon and make implementation changes difficult or impossible
for no good reason.  Marking this as INVALID; feel free to submit your requests
individually.

Private stuff is there to reduce maintenance costs. Once something is protected
we have to assume that a subclass is using it, and leave it alone forever. 

For the specifics of the <get> class, there is a set of http tasks in the antlib
SVN sandbox which is designed for subclassing, with <httppost>, <httpget> and
<httphead> already there for your use. Its not formally released, but if you
want to help bring it up to a released state (testing is the main barrier right
now), it would be welcome.
